add salt to water and its a good conductor but I woudnt want to see 110 vol=
ts flowing thru my pipes. and aluminum is out of the question for my home s=
o I wouldnt put it in anyone elses either. I treat every electrical job as =
if it was my own home. have to peoples lives depend on it even in the indus=
tries of the Greater Houston area where i work.Current doesnt flow thru wir=
e it flows around it.

links

--- On Wed, 5/27/09, Zack Widup <w9sz.zack@...> wrote:


From:=
 Zack Widup <w9sz.zack@...>
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Electrical Questio=
n
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wednesday, May 27, 2009, 9:52 AM






=



Silver is the best conductor known, with a conductivity of 63.01 E06 Sie=
mens per meter. Copper is next best at 59.6 E06 S/m. Gold is not the best, =
at 45.2 E06 S/m. Aluminum is much farther down, at 37.8 E06 S/m.
=A0
Silver=
 and gold are expensive.=A0They are usually used to plate RF assemblies whe=
re the skin effect takes=A0place (current doesn't flow uniformly through a =
conductor at RF frequencies but mainly travels=A0at the surface of the cond=
uctor).=A0Gold has the advantage that it never tarnishes or corrodes with m=
ost things it is exposed to. It's used a lot in contacts for rotary switche=
s and relays.
=A0
Zack


On Wed, May 27, 2009 at 9:38 AM, Golden Phoenix <g=
olden_phoenix42@ yahoo.com> wrote:













Firrst Electrical job I was=
 on as a helper in 1976 was to pick up a pole that was to feeding a house s=
omeone had wired in aluminum that had burned to the ground due to a bad con=
nection it had just been built. I had been with my old man on a many job si=
nhce I was 8 and never had seen anything like that. Copper is the only way =
to gold only better conductor is Gold. but who can handle that in a house. =
worste case of emf I have ever seen was a fancy chandaler that someone had =
over sized bulbs in and that thing flared up the whole house to very danger=
ous levels. when they say 60 watt max they mean it for your own safety. thi=
s thing had around 10 100 watt bulbs in it and the emfs were causing all ki=
nds of nice images after 30 minutes in the house we were having them too. 
=

Aluminum wire=
 is a nightmare! The stuff tends to=A0overheat, oxidizes where interconnect=
ions are made and=A0will spark, etc. 
=A0
I bought a transformer at Gateway=
 Electronics in St. Louis=A0some years ago that looked like a great transfo=
rmer for a high-current 12 volt supply. The secondary appeared to be wound =
with #8 enameled wire. I found out the secondary was wound with aluminum wi=
re.=A0After I built the power supply and tried to get 20 amps from it but c=
ouldn't, I gave up on it and got another transformer wound with copper wire=
.

Zack

=A0

he boxes, and--when=A0I first started doign EVP recordings with white noise=
, if the=A0furnace happened to come on when I was recording a voice would r=
eport "it's on fire!".
=A0
=A0What if that house has aluminum wire?
=A0

Frank-S

Yes.=A0 Also faulty wiring, which is eve=
n more dangerous.
Also with flakey transformers or other power distribution=
 in the area, or power lines.
Perhaps you can check with some neighbors, an=
d see how their power is doing.

Hi All,
=A0
Is there someone here that can answer and electri=
cal question for me?
=A0
During the case that I recorded those possible EVP=
's-there was a loud tapping noise that seemed to come from the 2nd bedroom.=
 Upon checking my logs, every time one of=A0 these clicks were heard, there=
 would be an EMF spike in the livingroom. The 2nd bedroom is upstairs, the =
livingroom downstairs. The home owners have also reported that they have a =
touch lamp that comes on all the time by itself and the lights in the Kitch=
en will dim occasionally.
=A0
Now these taps are not consistent in timing, =
loudness or rhythm. Could this be the work of faulty breakers?
=A0
Thanks!
=
April

<DIV>Silver is the best conductor known, with a cond=
